title: Multi-focus - dog fur difference in scores table

content.question: Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.The healthiness of a dog’s fur can be evaluated using a quantitative description analysis (<math alttext="Q D A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>), where a standard process is used to score the fur from <math alttext="0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="100" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, with higher values indicating healthier furs.Suppose the probability is <math alttext="0.53" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.53</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> that a dog entered in a dog show with a large number of entries has a <math alttext="Q D A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> score of at least <math alttext="80" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>80</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Ellen, an evaluator at the dog show, selected a random sample of <math alttext="50" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> dogs from the population of all dogs entered in the dog show and recorded the <math alttext="Q D A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> score for each dog in the sample.(a) In the context of Ellen’s sample, interpret the meaning of the value computed by <math alttext="0.53 to the 50 power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0.53</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>50</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text: Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.The healthiness of a dog’s fur can be evaluated using a quantitative description analysis (<math alttext="Q D A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>), where a standard process is used to score the fur from <math alttext="0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="100" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, with higher values indicating healthier furs.Suppose the probability is <math alttext="0.53" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.53</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> that a dog entered in a dog show with a large number of entries has a <math alttext="Q D A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> score of at least <math alttext="80" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>80</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Ellen, an evaluator at the dog show, selected a random sample of <math alttext="50" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> dogs from the population of all dogs entered in the dog show and recorded the <math alttext="Q D A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> score for each dog in the sample.(a) In the context of Ellen’s sample, interpret the meaning of the value computed by <math alttext="0.53 to the 50 power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0.53</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>50</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The computer output below provides the summary statistics of the <math alttext="Q D A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> score for each of the <math alttext="50" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> dogs in Ellen’s sample. Min <math alttext="Q 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> Median <math alttext="Q 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> Max Mean Standard Deviation <math alttext="55" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>55</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="68" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>68</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="80" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>80</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="88" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>88</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="100" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="82" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>82</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="12" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> (b) Would it be unusual for a dog from Ellen’s sample to have a <math alttext="Q D A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> score of <math alttext="64" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>64</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>? Justify your answer.

(c) Consider the situation where the minimum value was incorrectly recorded as <math alttext="55" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>55</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and is actually <math alttext="65" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>65</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Describe the effect that an increase in a <math alttext="Q D A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> score from <math alttext="55" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>55</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="65" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>65</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> would have on the mean and interquartile range (<math alttext="I Q R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi><mi>Q</mi><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>) of Ellen’s sample. Explain your reasoning.

Ellen plans to use the sample data to investigate whether there is convincing statistical evidence that all dogs entered in the dog show have a mean <math alttext="Q D A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> score greater than <math alttext="80" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>80</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.(d) State, in words, the hypotheses for the appropriate test.

Assume all conditions for inference are met. The <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value of Ellen’s test was approximately <math alttext="0.122" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.122</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.(e) Interpret what the value <math alttext="0.122" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.122</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> measures in the context of the study.

Samantha, another evaluator, selected a new random sample from the population of all dogs entered in the dog show and also obtained a sample mean of <math alttext="82" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>82</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. She then conducted the same inference procedure as Ellen had in order to investigate whether there is convincing statistical evidence that all dogs entered in the dog show have a mean <math alttext="Q D A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> score greater than <math alttext="80" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>80</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. The <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value of Samantha’s test was approximately <math alttext="0.002" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.002</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.(f) Identify one possible difference between Ellen’s and Samantha’s samples that resulted in Samantha’s test having a smaller <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value. Explain how this difference results in a smaller <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value for Samantha’s test.

topic.text: 1.7: Summary Statistics for a Quantitative Variable

skill.text: Skill 1.F: Identify null and alternative hypotheses.
